response.answer_text: No, Boccherini didn’t compose operas - not plural - though he may have composed a single one. Here’s a list of Boccherini’s works for the theatre. G 524: Cefalo e Procri (lost)G 525: Un gioco di minuetto ballabili Op. 41G 526: Ballet espagnolG 527: Interlude to Picini's opera: La buona figliolaG 540: Clementina, zarzuelaG 541: Scene from 'Ines de Castro'G 542: Aria for the opera "L'Almeria" (lost)(List of compositions by Luigi Boccherini) Cefalo e Procri may have been an opera - the list isn’t helpful in that regard. (The catalogue compiler needs a refresher course in how to avoid ambiguity. It’s also hard to tell whether it’s just Boccherini’s Aria for the opera "L'Almeria" that’s lost, or the whole opera - composed by whom?) There’s another listed work that has many of the characteristics of opera - the two-act zarzuela Clementina, stated in the linked article as being the only complete stage work Boccherini composed. (So is the Ballet espagnol just a fragment of dance music?) He spent a number of years in Spain where zarzuela originated, and the Iberian influence is found in many of his works, such as the popular Guitar Quintet No. 4 with its Fandango finale, and the Guitar 5tet No 9, “La Ritirata di Madrid”. According to the information in the linked article on zarzuela, it isn’t the same as opera though it includes operatic arias, and even though Boccherini’s zarzuela was composed in 1786 during the Classical period with music that’s firmly in the Classical style, Clementina is what’s technically termed a ‘Baroque zarzuela’. It was one of the last of its kind to be written. A listener hearing the many excerpts from Clementina on YouTube would be forgiven for thinking it sounds like opera, but it’s actually not one. Here are just a couple of excerpts. Aria: ¡Ay de mí!  Terceto: Huid, corazones

Did Boccherini compose operas? There’s always the possibility of another opera of the time being his, or his work not surviving the years, but it doesn’t appear so. Boccherini wrote chamber music. That was his thing, and he did a lot of stuff in the spirit of Haydn. Hadyn wrote some operas, but that’ s just because his patron Prince Nikolaus Esterházy liked operas a lot at one point. There’s a reason we don’t play Haydn operas much anymore—they weren’t really his thing either. And Boccherini probably was able to tell if he ever heard/looked at a Haydn opera, instead preferring to look to Haydn’s chamber works for inspiration.
